description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Polar Bear.
title: All About the Polar Bear

slides.title: Introduction to the Polar Bear
slides.content: The polar bear (Ursus maritimus) is a large bear species native to the Arctic region. It is the largest living species of bear and among the largest land carnivores. Polar bears are well-adapted to their harsh Arctic environment and are considered marine mammals.

slides.title: Physical Adaptations
content: Polar bears have white fur that provides camouflage in snow and ice, plus a layer of blubber up to 4.5 inches thick for insulation.
Their large paws (up to 12 inches across) act like snowshoes, distributing weight and providing traction on ice.

slides.title: Hunting and Feeding
content: Polar bears are apex predators that primarily hunt seals, especially ringed and bearded seals, using various hunting techniques.
They have an excellent sense of smell, able to detect seals through 3 feet of ice from up to a kilometer away.

slides.title: Arctic Lifestyle
content: Polar bears are mostly solitary animals except during mating season and when mothers are raising cubs.
They travel vast distances across sea ice, with some bears traveling thousands of miles annually in search of food and mates.

slides.title: Conservation Challenges
content: Polar bears are threatened by climate change, which is causing sea ice to melt and reducing their hunting habitat.
They are also affected by pollution, oil development, and hunting. Listed as vulnerable, conservation focuses on reducing greenhouse gas emissions and protecting critical habitats.
